title: Minister Calls For Innovation In Housing Sector
text:
12 August 2015 16:54 CET Minister Calls For Innovation In Housing Sector By Daily Guide 
Deputy Minister of Water, Works and Housing, Samuel Yaw Adusei has called on key stakeholders in the nation's housing sector to be more innovative in order to help address the huge housing deficit in Ghana. 
Mr Adusei made the call in a statement to officially launch the sixth edition of the Multitv-HFC Habitat Fair held at the Accra Conference Centre recently. 
According to the Deputy Minister, the nation can only address the huge housing deficit through innovation and hard work. 
'It is only through innovation that players within the sector can make progress and impact the society,' he said. 
The housing deficit facing the country means we have to work hard in order to achieve. We also need to think innovatively and differently.' 
Data from the 2000 and 2010 Population and Housing Census showed a 55.5 percent increase in the demand for housing over the decade, and this puts the housing deficit at about 1.7 million units. 
The deputy minister reiterated that the government, through the Ministry of Water, Works and Housing, was working effortlessly to address the challenges in the housing sector. 
But government alone cannot do much in tackling the problem without the support of others, other stakeholders from the private sector must support government, he indicated. 
'The housing industry needs the support of the private sector. Indeed, our housing profile indicate that the private sector account for 95 percent of our housing stock in Ghana. And if we are to address the huge housing deficit in Ghana, then the Ministry of Works and Housing needs to engage the private sector.' 
As part of measures to provide shelter for poor Ghanaians, he said government had commenced the construction of thousands of affordable housing units in some selected communities across the country, with about 1,500 of them expected to be commissioned by President John Mahama in the second quarter of 2016. 
Mr. Adusei lauded the initiative of Multitv and HFC Bank, saying 'the ministry welcomes this kind of news because it does not only provide us the opportunity to transact and forge closer partnerships with stakeholders of our industry but create an opportunity for sustained interaction among stakeholders and enhance the cross-examination of ideas among our stakeholders.' 
The Fair About 86 exhibitors from the housing industry attended the fair and offered various products and housing solutions to prospective buyers. 
Head of Sales and Marketing, Multitv, Mordecal Quarshie, in a statement, indicated that the fair is a platform that seeks to bring together players within the housing industry to collectively find a solution to the nation's rising housing needs. 
He announced that the final edition of the fair would be held in Kumasi in November. 
General Manager of Mortgage and Technology at HFC Bank, headline sponsor of the fair, Charles Bonsu, said the fair has enabled HFC over the last five years to offer housing solutions to many Ghanaians at affordable rates. 
Mr. Bonsu said, 'The bank has been able to reach out to more Ghanaians who have been able to own homes for less than GHÂ¢60,000.'
